img.alt: Find more about Weather in Ravenna, OH

h2.u: Welcome to the Ravenna School District

div.p: You may have heard that Governor DeWine has asked school districts to continue conducting remote education through the end of the 2019-2020 school year. We are already doing this, and have plans in place for the rest of the year!

Regarding what many of you have asked about - graduation - we are currently formulating plans so that we may have some type of celebration for our seniors, which we are very proud of! More information to come when it’s available!

font.b: Please check back here and follow us on Facebook for updates.

div.b: Message to Ravenna School District Families -

span.font: Good afternoon, this is Dennis Honkala, Superintendent of the Ravenna School District with a few very important messages for all Ravenna Families:

Now that the Governor has closed our school buildings for the remainder of the school year, it is more important than ever to make sure that our remote and flexible learning program is continuing and that every student finishes strong! Students, make sure that you are in communication with your teachers and are completing all required assignments. Our staff will continue to provide instruction electronically. All students will be accountable at the end of the school year for their work. Please give your very best effort with all assignments. I will also be sharing information in the coming weeks as to our closing procedures, student celebrations, the collecting of chrome books, grades, returning student items, etc…

font.span: Second, as an ongoing reminder, we will be continuing our food distribution days. All Ravenna students are eligible to participate in our food distribution program. We will be distributing food bags at all 7 of our schools from 11:00 am to 1:00 pm., on Mondays and Thursdays. There will be volunteers to guide everyone through this process. If you are driving, please stay in your car and we will bring the food bags to you. Students need not be with you, but we do need the names of the children. You do NOT have to go to the school that your child attends in order to receive the food bags. PLEASE go to the school that is closest to you and pick up for ALL family members.

span.p: Also, our technology support team will be at Ravenna High School every Monday and Thursday as well from 11:00 am to 1:00 pm. They will be servicing or exchanging devises that are not working properly for all students in grades 1st through 12th.

font.span: And finally, please encourage everyone to stay positive and finish the school year strong. Remember, we will be communicating important information regarding the closing of the school year and those various procedures as we move through May. We will continue to update all families through phone, email, the district website and Facebook pages. Have a good evening.

div.b: Additional Resources for Ravenna School District Families

font.span: We hope everyone is staying safe & healthy, and keeping up with their learning! Our elementary school counselors have put together a Google Drive Folder full of resources for students and families. You will find the link to this folder below. Inside the folder, you will see a condensed version of all of the various things that have been floating around about virtual learning via social media, email and text.

br.span: Please refer to the "Master List for Families in Digital Learning" first. We have included various challenges, community resources, coping skills, covid-19 information, education & edutainment resources, technology & wifi services, as well as positivity resources.

Come back to this folder throughout the next couple of weeks, as we will continue to update it. Our hope is that we can provide some useful information that can make this challenging time a bit easier.

b.a: CLICK HERE to view this helpful folder of resources!!

div.font: Carlin Student Continues Service Project from Home

br.br: Earlier this year, a group of students from Carlin Elementary School visited Vista Veranda each month to read to residents. Vista Veranda is a local senior care center in Ravenna. One particular student from Mrs. Boltz's fourth grade class wanted to continue this service project from home. Carter decided to write his friend Bob a letter! He also hopes to be able to read to Bob soon through a virtual internet visit. Carter is pictured here delivering his letter to his friend! Thanks, Carter, for sharing some Raven kindness!

div.span: RHS Seniors Celebrated at Stadium "Drive In" Style

div.font: The lights were turned on at Ravenna Stadium for 20 minutes on April 20th at 8:20 p.m. (20:20 military time) to salute the class of 2020!!! Many high schools across northeast Ohio participated in similar events at the same time. Ohio schools turned on their stadium lights as a way to honor this year's senior class. Families and well wishers drove to the stadium and remained in their vehicles, respecting social distancing mandates, and cheered and honked their horns.

div.span: RHS 3-D Printer is Being Used to Produce Face Masks

br.br: Ravenna High School's Integrated Production Technology class is fortunate to have a 3-dimensional printer. During this global crisis, it is being utilized to help fight Covid-19 locally and throughout northeast Ohio. Our 3-dimensional printer is being used to print masks for Project Govern out of North Olmsted and is continuing to print around the clock. Thus far, we have printed 44 masks. They are distributed to Cleveland Clinic, Metro Health, University Hospitals and Lake Health. After the mask pieces are donated, they are disinfected and fully assembled with clear plastic pieces donated by the Prusa Corporation before going out to the medical facilities. The masks are sent to this facility and then properly fitted and fixed up for distribution to area hospitals. UH (University Hospitals) is one of the hospitals.

span.font: Amanda Rufener, a Ravenna School District parent who works at Total Lifetime Care Center in Garrettsville, was very excited to receive some of the masks we have produced! This local medical practice has been trying to purchase shields but has not been able to get them. They received 5 that were made with our 3-D printer and Amanda sends their sincere thanks!

div.span: Mystery Reader Delights Kindergarteners with Virtual Visit

div.font: Kindergarten Art Teacher Features Student Artist

br.br:
Today's featured artist is Elijah!
"Elijah has grown so much as an artist. He has worked so hard and it shows! My heart is so happy when I ask him if he's proud of himself, and he looks up at me with the biggest smile and says "yes." Elijah, I am so proud of you! I miss getting you out of the car in the morning and I miss seeing you in art!"
~Ms. Kelle Arthur
Art Teacher
West Park School

div.span: Students Making the Best of Learning at Home

font.span: Ravenna students are thriving and making the best of learning at home during this unprecedented time. Pictured below is Willyard first grader, Cameron Minnick. He says he is having a good time doing his work at home even though he does miss school! His teacher, Mrs. Biltz, says he is a good worker! We hope these make you smile!

div.span: Cameron is writing sight words on a family member's back!
He is practicing his spelling words with a CHEER!
His class is reading about The Three Wolves and the Big Bad Pig!

div.font: Cam is checking speed on different types of material for science.

div.span: He is acting out The 3 Pigs and he is the pig! His dog was the "stand in" wolf!

div.font: BMS Science Class Enjoys Creating Video Projects

span.font: Mrs. Stefansic's 7th grade science class recently completed an Earth, Sun, & Moon Unit and the students did EXTREMELY well learning at home. The average score on the unit test was 94%!! Way to go!! Mrs. Stefansic assigned her students a project that involved making a model or creating a one person skit to demonstrate something they learned . They were then instructed to film a video using familiar technology which they had used all year to be shared with the class. Students were encouraged to get the whole family involved. Here are a sample of some of their projects.

div.span: Art Lessons Continue at Home for West Main Students

font.b: Words of Encouragement from our Staff

font.a: Click HERE to view an inspirational video from the staff at West Main!

div.h4: Officer Staple Covid 19-2020 Year Tribute Video

strong.em: Responses to the 2020 Census shape decisions about how billions of dollars in federal funds flow into communities each year for the next 10 years for critical services.

Health care, emergency response, schools and education programs, and roads and bridges are all impacted by the 2020 Census. The COVID-19 pandemic underscores the importance of census data and census participation.
Counting everyone living in a community helps community leaders plan for the future. Where there are more people, there are often greater needs.

li.em: Census results inform planning and funding decisions for communities for critical public services. These services include:
Hospitals, health clinics, and health care services
Emergency and disaster response, fire, and public safety services
Schools, education programs, grants, and more
Roads, bridges, and other public transit and infrastructure projects
Housing services and programs for special populations
The COVID-19 pandemic underscores the importance of census data.

font.a: What is Portage County doing to respond to 2019 novel Coronavirus?

div.h4: Ohio Department of Health Opens Call Center to Help With COVID-19 Response

div.div:
Ohio Department of Health Opens Call Center to Help With COVID-19 Response
1-833-4-ASK-ODH Open Seven Days a Week
(COLUMBUS, Ohio)— Ohio Department of Health Director Amy Acton, MD, MPH, today announced the Ohio Department of Health (ODH) has opened a call center to answer questions regarding coronavirus (COVID-19). The call center will be open 7 days a week from 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. and can be reached at 1-833-4-ASK-ODH (1-833-427-5634).
Call center staff includes licensed nurses and infectious disease experts. They will be available to answer questions and provide accurate information about COVID-19, the risk to the public, and the state’s response.
The number of potential cases and the results of testing are regularly updated every weekday at coronavirus.ohio.gov.
While the general risk to the public in Ohio is still considered low, it is important to continue to follow standard precautions to prevent the spread of infectious disease. To prevent the spread of any virus including novel coronavirus, practice these preventative measures:
Wash your hands often with soap and water.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Additional information and guidance on COVID-19 is available at ODH’s new website, coronavirus.ohio.gov.

div.h4: Tips for Keeping Yourself and Others Healthy

font.u: TIPS FOR KEEPING YOURSELF AND OTHERS HEALTHY:

font.face: Helvetica Neue, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, sans-serif

li.font: Stay home when you are sick. If possible, stay home from work, school, and errands when you are sick. You will help prevent others from catching your illness. Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth. Germs spread this way.
Cover coughs and sneezes. Use a tissue to cover coughs and sneezes, then dispose of the tissue. When a tissue is not available, cough or sneeze into your elbow.

Clean and disinfect surfaces or objects. Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces at home, work or school, especially when someone is ill. Find additional CDC resources on how to clean and disinfect schools.

Wash hands for 20 seconds. Washing hands often under clean, running water can help prevent the spread of germs. For more guidance see the CDC: When and How to Wash Your Hands. If you cannot wash your hands, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60-95% alcohol.

br.br:
* Currently, you are only at risk if you (1) are displaying symptoms; and (2) have traveled to China in the 14 days before feeling sick or have been in contact with someone who has confirmed COVID-19. By and large, travel history is key.
* People who have been diagnosed with COVID-19 have reported symptoms including fever, cough, and difficulty breathing that may appear in as few as two days or as many as 14 days after exposure to the virus. At this point you are more likely to catch the flu or a common cold, which both show some of the same symptoms.
* ODH recommends precautions used for reducing the risk of infection for other illnesses, such as flu. Encourage staff, children, and families to follow these precautions at all times.
* Frequently wash your hands for 20 seconds or more with soapy water. If unavailable, use hand sanitizer.
* Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
* Avoid contact with people who are sick.
* Stay home when you are sick (except to visit a health care professional) and avoid contact with others.
* Cover your mouth/nose with a tissue or sleeve when coughing or sneezing.
* Get adequate sleep and eat well-balanced meals to ensure a healthy immune system.

div.a: FAQs for Ohio Schools and Districts

div.b: Doe v. Ohio Department of Education Settlement Proposal

span.font: The parties in the Doe v. Ohio Department of Education class action have submitted a proposed settlement to the U.S. District Court for approval. The first step in the approval process of the settlement is to provide notice of the proposed settlement to affected students and their parents.

b.a: Please click here to view the proposed settlement.

div.font: The Ravenna School District is an Equal Opportunity Employer. The Board of Education does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, creed, disability, religion, gender, ancestry, age, military status or national origin in its programs, activities or employment.
